sub_topic: Probability of a certain outcome in a sports game
message_1: A basketball player has a free throw shooting percentage of 85%. If they shoot 10 free throws in a game, what is the probability that they will make exactly 7 of them?
message_2:
We can use the binomial probability formula to solve this problem. The formula is:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of having exactly k successes in n trials
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- n is the number of trials (in this case, 10 free throws)
- k is the number of successes (in this case, 7 successful free throws)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, 0.85)
- (1-p) is the probability of failure (in this case, 1 - 0.85 = 0.15)

First, we need to calculate C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 successful free throws out of 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
          = 10! / (7! * 3!)
          = (10 * 9 * 8) / (3 * 2 * 1)
          = 120

Now, we can plug the values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 7) = C(10, 7) * 0.85^7 * 0.15^3
         = 120 * 0.85^7 * 0.15^3
         â‰ˆ 0.266

So, the probability that the basketball player will make exactly 7 out of 10 free throws is approximately 0.266 or 26.6%.
